Usability & UX: Sticky header with a toggleable mobile menu, clear ‚ÄúExplore Flavors‚Äù call-to-action buttons, and a legible, well-spaced layout on all screen sizes.


Creativity: CSS-animated 3D donut in the hero section with rotating icing, drips, and animated sprinkles. Custom SVG background patterns in hero and contact sections to ‚Ä¶

Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Design (v9.0.5) in ASP.NET Core Web API


In the evolving world of backend development, scaffolding and code generation are crucial for productivity, maintainability, and scaling real-world .NET solutions. One of the most powerful yet often underutilized tools in the Entity Framework Core ecosystem is the Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Design package.
In this blog, we‚Äôll explore:
What the Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Design package offers
Why version 9.0.5 matters in modern .NET development
Step-by-step tutorial: scaffolding a real database into a clean API structure
Best practices to use it professionally
Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Design?


Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Design is a helper package that brings the design-time tools necessary to scaffold DbC‚Ä¶

articles.author: Kevin Juli√°n Mart√≠nez Escobar
articles.description:
In this post, I‚Äôll walk you through how to set up a React app using Vite and TypeScript with Vitest and React Testing Library.
This kind of setup isn‚Äôt included by default in Vite, and it can be a bit tedious the first time you try it. So, here‚Äôs a quick guide to help you get everything running smoothly.
If you prefer to skip the explanations and just want the final result, you can jump to the summary section at the end, where I list all the required installations and final file versions.
Start by creating a new Vite app:
npm create vite@latest

When prompted, name the project:
react-testing-configuration-example

Then choose:
Framework: react

Variant: TypeScript




Now install dependencies and start the dev server:
cd react-testing-configuration-example
npm install
npm run dev

You shou‚Ä¶
articles.title: React Testing Setup: Vitest + TypeScript + React Testing Library

articles.author: Chitransh Soral
articles.description:
Yep! you read that right, my ambitious project manager is now 50% complete and it is building with CMake too.
Now you guys might be asking that what changed so drastically in one day that from complete hopelessness, I present you this good news. Well, I would like to remind you that yesterday only I said that "IF days like today happen", which I can assure you guys that this quote didn't age well.
Today I had much more time to focus on the project and I did that. Yesterday, I had just got to know about the cURL library that is used to send the HTTP requests in C++. But today, I imported the library, went through the documentation and with the help of some chatbots, was able to build functions to download and extract packages from Pypi.
Thunder Client, I got to know that I am receiving JSON from Pypi. But I don't know how to parse JSON in C++, so using AI I found that I need to use nlohmann json.
That will be my task for tomorrow and after deadlock is able to handle packages easily while using the virtual environment, 
Thank you, guys for your support ü´°
articles.title: DeadLock - 50% Complete

articles.author: Vritika
articles.description:
"DNA is like a computer program but far, far more advanced than any software ever created."
Do you remember the days when we used to buy CDs to play GTA on our computers, or when we saved our summer vacation pictures on a pen drive?

Around 5.74 million terabytes of data is generated each second. (1 Terabyte = 10^12 bytes).
Letters from World War I
Photos on your phone
Scientific simulations
Social media videos
Massive ‚Äúbig data‚Äù from sensors, servers, and AI.
The graph below shows the dramatic surge in the digital data generated in the past two decades and what can we expect in the next one.

Sure, cloud storage is  growing rapidly‚Äîbut storing all this data purely on the cloud is theoretically possible, yet practically very difficult due to cost, infrastructure, and energy limitations.
It‚Ä¶
articles.title: CDs to DNA: The Future of Data Storage üß¨

articles.author: Dalton A. Breshears, J.D.
articles.description:
AI is no longer just a buzzword in the legal world‚Äîit's becoming a practical tool that law firms are using to dramatically speed up their workflows, especially when it comes to drafting motions, contracts, and legal research.
Faster Legal Research: Instead of spending hours combing through case law, attorneys are using AI-powered platforms like Lexis+ AI and Westlaw Precision to get contextual, relevant case summaries in seconds. These tools don‚Äôt just search‚Äîthey understand legal language and deliver insights, saving valuable time.
Drafting Motions & Contracts: AI tools like Harvey, CoCounsel by CaseText, and Spellbook are helping lawyers generate first drafts of everything from simple demand letters to complex motions. These platforms suggest clauses, format citations, and even flag potential risks‚Äîmaking it easier to move from outline to final draft in a fraction of the time.
Smarter Document Review: AI-powered review tools can now analyze contracts, flag missing provisions, and compare documents against standard templates. This is especially useful for due diligence, compliance checks, and M&A work.
Efficiency = Profitability: For law firms, time is literally money. By using AI to reduce manual work, they can focus on higher-level strategic thinking, serve more clients, and maintain accuracy under pressure.
AI isn‚Äôt replacing lawyers‚Äîit‚Äôs helping them work faster, smarter, and more effectively. The firms adopting these tools today are gaining a competitive edge in both service quality and speed.
articles.title: How Law Firms Are Using AI to Draft Faster and Work Smarter

articles.author: Andrey Matveyev
articles.description:
Hello everyone! This is my first post on this platform, and I'm kicking it off with a small publication. Happy reading!
In the Go world, pipelines built on channels are powerful tools for organizing streaming data processing. However, standard channels don't always provide all the necessary flexibility, especially when you need to manage data flow between producers and consumers operating at different speeds, and avoid busy-waiting.
Consider a typical data processing pipeline:
Producer (Fast) -> Stage 1 (Medium) -> Stage 2 (Slow) -> Consumer (Variable)
Our Go queue will have the following characteristics:
Non-blocking Producer/Consumer: Adding to or taking from the queue should not block the respective goroutines unnecessarily.
Context-aware Consumer: The consumer (reading from the queue) ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Building a Queue for Go Pipelines

articles.author: The Adventures of Scuba Jack
articles.description:
Learning through Play: Building Blocks of Early Growth
Children flourish when play and learning go hand in hand. In the early years of development, playful environments foster social skills, coordination, and cognitive abilities. One of the most effective ways to support these early stages is through engaging Kindergarten children's games. These games are not just for entertainment‚Äîthey introduce problem-solving, sharing, counting, and language basics in exciting ways. Structured play allows kids to experiment, fail safely, and grow without the pressure of traditional instruction.

Interactive Digital Tools That Support Early Education
With rapid digital advancements, kids today have access to interactive platforms that support their learning needs beyond the classroom. An E Learning Websi‚Ä¶
articles.title: Spark Curiosity with Fun and Learning Every Day

articles.author: Rijul Rajesh
articles.description:
If you're starting with Rust, you've probably heard about Cargo. It‚Äôs the official package manager and build system for Rust, and it handles almost everything you need to get your Rust project up and running‚Äîfrom compiling code to managing dependencies. In this article, we‚Äôll take a closer look at how dependency management works using Cargo.toml.
Cargo.toml?


When you create a new Rust project using the command:
cargo new my_project

Cargo sets up a new project directory with a file called Cargo.toml. This file is the heart of your project configuration. It contains metadata about your project‚Äîlike its name, version, and authors‚Äîand, more importantly, a list of dependencies.
Here‚Äôs a simplified example of what a Cargo.toml might look like:
[package]
name = "my_project"
version = "0.1.0"
e‚Ä¶
articles.title: Getting Started with Dependency Management in Rust Using Cargo.toml

articles.author: JetThoughts Dev
articles.description:
Around 4 million people in the US and Europe work in compliance and audit. Compliance costs are going up. Regulations keep expanding. Traditional compliance tasks need reading dense rules, checking internal policy, sampling work, and making reports. Auditors often look through lots of data to find problems. These manual workflows need automation.
Compliance costs are on the rise. This is due to many new rules. These rules cover everything from data privacy to financial reporting. Businesses must follow these rules. This takes a lot of time and effort. It also costs a lot of money.
Compliance work has always been manual. People read long documents. They check policies. They look at samples of work. They write many reports. Auditors spend hours sifting through data. They look for issues. This work is slow. It takes a lot of time.
Large Language Models (LLMs) are good at this work. They can read many documents. These include rules, policies, and financial statements. They can find problems. This saves human review time. These tools will automate much of the testing auditors do by hand.
  Spotting data anomalies.
  Finding incomplete records.
  Highlighting conflicting policies.
Instead of checking a few documents, a good model can look at everything. It can do this all at once. It can continuously audit every company. This makes compliance faster and more accurate.
articles.title: Compliance and Audit
